metadata.chapter: Chapter 4: Bayesian Filtering and State Estimation

questions.stem: In the Bayes filter algorithm, what does the PREDICT step compute?

options.text: The posterior probability distribution given the new observation
The prior probability distribution by propagating the previous estimate through the motion model
The likelihood of the current observation given the state
The normalization constant for the probability distribution

questions.explanation: The PREDICT step (also called the prediction or propagation step) computes the prior distribution P(x_t | u_{1:t-1}, z_{1:t-1}) by applying the motion/control model to the previous posterior. The UPDATE step then incorporates the new observation to compute the posterior.
learning_objectives: LO-4.1: Understand the two-step structure of Bayes filter (predict and update)
LO-4.2: Explain the purpose of each step in the Bayes filter algorithm

capstone_alignment.relevance: Understanding predict/update structure is foundational for implementing any Bayesian filter variant

common_misconceptions: Confusing predict with update - students often think predict incorporates observations
Thinking predict computes the posterior instead of the prior

questions.stem: The Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) linearizes nonlinear functions using which method?

options.text: First-order Taylor series expansion around the current estimate

questions.explanation: The EKF linearizes nonlinear functions (transition and observation models) using first-order Taylor series expansion. It computes Jacobian matrices at the current state estimate to approximate the nonlinear functions as linear functions, then applies the standard Kalman filter equations to this linearized system.
learning_objectives: LO-4.3: Compare EKF and UKF approaches to handling nonlinearities
LO-4.4: Explain how linearization is performed in EKF

capstone_alignment.relevance: EKF is commonly used in robotics; understanding its linearization approach is essential

common_misconceptions: Confusing EKF with UKF - thinking EKF uses sigma points
Believing EKF uses second-order Taylor series (it's first-order)
Thinking EKF samples points like a particle filter
